# The `LoopVectorizationLegality` Class Reference

<DoxygenPage pluginConfig={pluginConfig}>

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/loopvectorizationlegality">LoopVectorizationLegality</a> checks if it is legal to vectorize a loop, and to what vectorization factor. <a href="#details">More...</a>

## Declaration

<CodeBlock>class llvm::LoopVectorizationLegality</CodeBlock>

## Description {#details}

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/loopvectorizationlegality">LoopVectorizationLegality</a> checks if it is legal to vectorize a loop, and to what vectorization factor.

This class does not look at the profitability of vectorization, only the legality. This class has two main kinds of checks:
<ul>
<li><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sys/memory">Memory</a> checks - The code in canVectorizeMemory checks if vectorization will change the order of memory accesses in a way that will change the correctness of the program.</li>
<li>Scalars checks - The code in canVectorizeInstrs and canVectorizeMemory checks for a number of different conditions, such as the availability of a single induction variable, that all types are supported and vectorize-able, etc. This code reflects the capabilities of <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/innerloopvectorizer">InnerLoopVectorizer</a>. This class is also used by <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/innerloopvectorizer">InnerLoopVectorizer</a> for identifying induction variable and the different reduction variables.</li>
</ul>

Definition at line 252 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/transforms/include/llvm/transforms/vectorize/loopvectorizationlegality-h">LoopVectorizationLegality.h</a>.

### canVectorize() {#a3ce10d1174bdfcac2b73ed7efa352b7f}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="bool llvm::LoopVectorizationLegality::canVectorize (bool UseVPlanNativePath)">
Returns true if it is legal to vectorize this loop.

This does not mean that it is profitable to vectorize this loop, only that it is legal to do so. Temporarily taking UseVPlanNativePath parameter. If true, take the new code path being implemented for outer loop vectorization (should be functional for inner loop vectorization) based on <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/vplan">VPlan</a>. If false, good old LV code.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/transforms/include/llvm/transforms/vectorize/loopvectorizationlegality-h/#l00283">283</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/transforms/include/llvm/transforms/vectorize/loopvectorizationlegality-h">LoopVectorizationLegality.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/vectorize/loopvectorizationlegality-cpp/#l01762">1762</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/vectorize/loopvectorizationlegality-cpp">LoopVectorizationLegality.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

Vectorizing is legal if we allow reordering of FP operations, or if we can use in-order reductions.

### isConsecutivePtr() {#a4589ea484ebe1919b451fff3948a17cc}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>int llvm::LoopVectorizationLegality::isConsecutivePtr (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42; AccessTy, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; Ptr) const</>}>
<a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/check">Check</a> if this pointer is consecutive when vectorizing.

This happens when the last index of the GEP is the induction variable, or that the pointer itself is an induction variable. This check allows us to vectorize A&#91;idx&#93; into a wide load/store. Returns: 0 - Stride is unknown or non-consecutive. 1 - Address is consecutive. -1 - Address is consecutive, and decreasing. NOTE: This method must only be used before modifying the original scalar loop. Do not use after invoking &#39;createVectorizedLoopSkeleton&#39; (PR34965).

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/transforms/include/llvm/transforms/vectorize/loopvectorizationlegality-h/#l00362">362</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/transforms/include/llvm/transforms/vectorize/loopvectorizationlegality-h">LoopVectorizationLegality.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/vectorize/loopvectorizationlegality-cpp/#l00454">454</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/vectorize/loopvectorizationlegality-cpp">LoopVectorizationLegality.cpp</a>.

### blockCanBePredicated() {#aeb9b746c802505da2247f2d2252b6b43}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool llvm::LoopVectorizationLegality::blockCanBePredicated (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/basicblock">BasicBlock</a> &#42; BB, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/smallptrsetimpl">SmallPtrSetImpl</a>&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; &gt; &amp; SafePtrs, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/smallptrsetimpl">SmallPtrSetImpl</a>&lt; <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42; &gt; &amp; MaskedOp) const</>}>
Return true if all of the instructions in the block can be speculatively executed, and record the loads/stores that require masking.

<code>SafePtrs</code> is a list of addresses that are known to be legal and we know that we can read from them without segfault. <code>MaskedOp</code> is a list of instructions that have to be transformed into calls to the appropriate masked intrinsic when the loop is vectorized or dropped if the instruction is a conditional assume intrinsic.

### isVectorizableEarlyExitLoop() {#a0961a8a5109f7d5c34a2313293e602e2}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="bool llvm::LoopVectorizationLegality::isVectorizableEarlyExitLoop ()">
Returns true if this is an early exit loop that can be vectorized.

Currently, a loop with an uncountable early exit is considered vectorizable if:
<ul>
<li>There are no writes to memory in the loop.</li>
<li>The loop has only one early uncountable exit</li>
<li>The early exit block dominates the latch block.</li>
<li>The latch block has an exact exit count.</li>
<li>The loop does not contain reductions or recurrences.</li>
<li>We can prove at compile-time that loops will not contain faulting loads.</li>
<li>It is safe to speculatively execute instructions such as divide or call instructions. The list above is not based on theoretical limitations of vectorization, but simply a statement that more work is needed to support these additional cases safely.</li>
</ul>

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/transforms/include/llvm/transforms/vectorize/loopvectorizationlegality-h/#l00529">529</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/transforms/include/llvm/transforms/vectorize/loopvectorizationlegality-h">LoopVectorizationLegality.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/vectorize/loopvectorizationlegality-cpp/#l01612">1612</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/vectorize/loopvectorizationlegality-cpp">LoopVectorizationLegality.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### PSE {#a3bdd6f36c94c7915cb98d7ad501a49be}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>PredicatedScalarEvolution&amp; llvm::LoopVectorizationLegality::PSE</>}>
A wrapper around <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scalarevolution">ScalarEvolution</a> used to add runtime <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scev">SCEV</a> checks.

Applies dynamic knowledge to simplify <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scev">SCEV</a> expressions in the context of existing <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scev">SCEV</a> assumptions. The analysis will also add a minimal set of new predicates if this is required to enable vectorization and unrolling.
